area_name: Martin Tudor Jurupa Hills Regional Park

content.description: Fun, safe, traverse requiring no crash pad (or crashpad optional).  Start at the right of the formation. Move left.  Stay about 1 to 4 feet off the ground. Towards the right, it will get more difficult and come up over some smaller boulders, towards the start of the Charred Shrub route. Follow it, you won't need to worry about being over those small boulders for this because you should stay less than a foot and a half above them.  If you fall on them you won't fall backwards, they form a little protective ledge.  The crux is towards the end, it becomes challenging slab climbing. It starts easy and get's harder so it's ideal for new climbers if you want to hop on and see how far you can get.
content.protection: Low traverse.  Crashpad optional if you follow as recommended.
content.location: Set out on the trail that starts from the south end of the southmost parking lot.  All the parking lots are connected so this won't be hard to find.Sierra avenue is visible running parallel 20 feet to your left.  Walk about 75 feet on this trail.  You should pass the tunnel on your left by 15 feet.  Look directly right.  You should be in a burnt shrub area (at least as of 2021) and there's a formation of rocks kind of nestled into the hill with an unobstructed approach about 15 feet to your right (15 feet west of the trail).  There is a boulder on the left that sticks out front a bit.  If you go right of that boulder, to the edge of the continuous rock there, that's the start.

content.description: This problem is the main line up this boulder.  It's the longest way up, and kind of central to the formation.  You're on route if you face a more steep area starting about 5 feet up and lasting 4 feet. Kind of a tough place to get a crash pad in nicely, so try to pre-empt falls and jump a bit to the right, or traverse out of the problem.
content.location: Set out on the trail that starts from the south end of the southmost parking lot.  All the parking lots are connected so this won't be hard to find.Sierra avenue is visible running parallel 20 feet to your left.  Walk about 75 feet on this trail.  You should pass the tunnel on your left by 15 feet.  Look directly right.  You should be in a burnt shrub area (at least as of 2021) and there's a formation of rocks kind of nestled into the hill with an unobstructed approach about 15 feet to your right (15 feet west of the trail).  There is a boulder on the left that sticks out front a bit.  If you go right of that boulder, there's a 2 foot by 2 foot boulder at the base of the main face.  Start to the right of this boulder as seen in the photo.  I would place the crash pad there as well and try to fall to the right.

climbs.name: To the left, to the left

content.description: Go to the left of the crack and climb the face.  Easiest is to go a little to the left as you get up around 3 feet off of the ground, then come back to the right a little bit. There's a bit of contact with the tree as you climb.  Try not to mess up the tree.  At the top, watch out for a big rock (1 foot by 1 foot) after you've topped out. Seems a little unstable.  Can come down around the back.
content.protection: Crashpad and spotter needed.  Could set up a top rope if you really wanted.
content.location: Park in the upper parking lot of Martin Tudor Jurupa Hills Park.  Park to the left of the upper parking lot, by the grassy park area to the left of the jungle gym.  Walk directly west up over the grass to the little trail that cuts up to the main trail.  The little shortcut trail is 10 feet long and intersects perpendicular to the bigger trail which runs north-south.  Turn right on the bigger trail (north) and go 10 feet. The boulder will be on your left.  A 15 foot boulder with a big crack running down the middle and a tree growing out of the top.

pathTokens: Martin Tudor Jurupa Hills Regional Park
